answers.author: Steven Barkley
answers.text:
The City of Durango coordinates  multiple parades through out the year with non-profits. Our approximate fees that we charge are: $204 traffic control plan and set, $37 per m/h for city employees, $65 per m/h for PD officers, event permit $75.
For the one parade that the city operates on July 4th the estimated costs to the city are about $500 for a 6 block parade, this would not include advertising.

The City of Wilsonville has begun having enough requests for parades and fun runs, 1/2 marathons, etc. that use public streets, intersections and sidewalks that we developes a 'streets and sidewalks' permit to manage the route, crossing difficulties, notices for traffic control, staging area coordination, etc. of these events that are different than park activities that remain in one place.   I am attaching the document, which will make it easier to see how the fees and requirements are applied.   Good Luck!

author: Pamela Muse
text:
The City of Sunnyvale, CA is gearing up for a parade celebrating their centennial.  They are interested in costing information that you might be able to provide re: the parade(s) you’ve coordinated in you agency.  Obviously there are many contingencies, such as police overtime rates, size of parade etc., but, whatever data you might have that says for example, “our city sponsored a one mile parade and it cost approximately $__”, would be hugely helpful.  Or, if you could provide a "guesstimate" of staff hours devoted to planning and conducting the parade would be useful too.
